commit_message:
Added exception handling in capture_stdio for handling scenerios when
logger is not working and swift tries to use logger to write uncaught
exceptions in it.

Change-Id: I5a248c372ac005d25df106205e2f4b06d2fd601a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/35/108235/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: sys.excepthook = lambda * exc_info: \ logger.critical(_('UNCAUGHT EXCEPTION'), exc_info=exc_info) except: print "unhandled exception occured while logging uncaught exception in system logger"
deleted_lines: sys.excepthook = lambda * exc_info: \ logger.critical(_('UNCAUGHT EXCEPTION'), exc_info=exc_info)

commit_message:
The python-qpid packages must be installed when qpidd is configured

The python-qpid package is available for Ubuntu trusty, precise, and
all the supported RHEL based platforms.  This package is necessary if
qpidd is configured as the RPC backend.  It is the client API used to
talk to the broker, and must be installed on each system that
communicates with the broker.

Change-Id: I635d3e857aa4b769a80cb7cde405cfd6cae44d32
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/59/121659/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # If using the QPID broker, install the QPID python client API if is_service_enabled qpid || [ -n "$QPID_HOST" ]; then install_package python-qpid fi

commit_message:
Added missing direct backend APIs and unit test for it

Added some missing direct backend APIs and unit test for
both account and container.

Change-Id: I5bc283f4454c3deff904ef956a53747bde4e5f0f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/19/84819/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def direct_put_account(node, part, account, conn_timeout=5, response_timeout=15, headers=None): """ Request account put directly from the account server. :param node: node dictionary from the ring :param part: partition the account is on :param account: account name :param conn_timeout: timeout in seconds for establishing the connection :param response_timeout: timeout in seconds for getting the response :param headers: additional headers to include in the request :returns: a dict containing the response's headers (all header names will be lowercase) """ path = '/%s' % (account) with Timeout(conn_timeout): conn = http_connect(node['ip'], node['port'], node['device'], part, 'PUT', path, headers=gen_headers(headers, True)) with Timeout(response_timeout): resp = conn.getresponse() resp.read() if not is_success(resp.status): raise ClientException( 'Account server %s:%s direct PUT %s gave status %s' % (node['ip'], node['port'], repr('/%s/%s%s' % (node['device'], part, path)), resp.status), http_host=node['ip'], http_port=node['port'], http_device=node['device'], http_status=resp.status, http_reason=resp.reason) resp_headers = {} for header, value in resp.getheaders(): resp_headers[header.lower()] = value return resp_headers def direct_head_account(node, part, account, conn_timeout=5, response_timeout=15): """ Request account head directly from the account server. :param node: node dictionary from the ring :param part: partition the account is on :param account: account name :param conn_timeout: timeout in seconds for establishing the connection :param response_timeout: timeout in seconds for getting the response :returns: a dict containing the response's headers (all header names will be lowercase) """ path = '/%s' % (account) with Timeout(conn_timeout): conn = http_connect(node['ip'], node['port'], node['device'], part, 'HEAD', path, headers=gen_headers()) with Timeout(response_timeout): resp = conn.getresponse() resp.read() if not is_success(resp.status): raise ClientException( 'Account server %s:%s direct HEAD %s gave status %s' % (node['ip'], node['port'], repr('/%s/%s%s' % (node['device'], part, path)), resp.status), http_host=node['ip'], http_port=node['port'], http_device=node['device'], http_status=resp.status, http_reason=resp.reason) resp_headers = {} for header, value in resp.getheaders(): resp_headers[header.lower()] = value return resp_headers def direct_post_account(node, part, account, headers, conn_timeout=5, response_timeout=15): """ Request account post directly from the account server. :param node: node dictionary from the ring :param part: partition the account is on :param account: account name :param conn_timeout: timeout in seconds for establishing the connection :param response_timeout: timeout in seconds for getting the response :param headers: headers to store as metadata :returns: a dict containing the response's headers (all header names will be lowercase) """ path = '/%s' % (account) with Timeout(conn_timeout): conn = http_connect(node['ip'], node['port'], node['device'], part, 'POST', path, headers=gen_headers(headers, True)) with Timeout(response_timeout): resp = conn.getresponse() resp.read() if not is_success(resp.status): raise ClientException( 'Account server %s:%s direct POST %s gave status %s' % (node['ip'], node['port'], repr('/%s/%s%s' % (node['device'], part, path)), resp.status), http_host=node['ip'], http_port=node['port'], http_device=node['device'], http_status=resp.status, http_reason=resp.reason) resp_headers = {} for header, value in resp.getheaders(): resp_headers[header.lower()] = value return resp_headers def direct_delete_account(node, part, account, conn_timeout=5, response_timeout=15, headers=None): """ Request account delete directly from the account server. :param node: node dictionary from the ring :param part: partition the account is on :param account: account name :param conn_timeout: timeout in seconds for establishing the connection :param response_timeout: timeout in seconds for getting the response :returns: a dict containing the response's headers (all header names will be lowercase) """ path = '/%s' % (account) with Timeout(conn_timeout): conn = http_connect(node['ip'], node['port'], node['device'], part, 'DELETE', path, headers=gen_headers(headers, True)) with Timeout(response_timeout): resp = conn.getresponse() resp.read() if not is_success(resp.status): raise ClientException( 'Account server %s:%s direct DELETE %s gave status %s' % (node['ip'], node['port'], repr('/%s/%s%s' % (node['device'], part, path)), resp.status), http_host=node['ip'], http_port=node['port'], http_device=node['device'], http_status=resp.status, http_reason=resp.reason) resp_headers = {} for header, value in resp.getheaders(): resp_headers[header.lower()] = value return resp_headers def direct_put_container(node, part, account, container, conn_timeout=5, response_timeout=15, headers=None): """ Request container put directly from the container server. :param node: node dictionary from the ring :param part: partition the container is on :param account: account name :param container: container name :param conn_timeout: timeout in seconds for establishing the connection :param response_timeout: timeout in seconds for getting the response :param headers: additional headers to include in the request :returns: a dict containing the response's headers (all header names will be lowercase) """ path = '/%s/%s' % (account, container) if headers is None: headers = {} with Timeout(conn_timeout): conn = http_connect(node['ip'], node['port'], node['device'], part, 'PUT', path, headers=gen_headers(headers, True)) with Timeout(response_timeout): resp = conn.getresponse() resp.read() if not is_success(resp.status): raise ClientException( 'Container server %s:%s direct PUT %s gave status %s' % (node['ip'], node['port'], repr('/%s/%s%s' % (node['device'], part, path)), resp.status), http_host=node['ip'], http_port=node['port'], http_device=node['device'], http_status=resp.status, http_reason=resp.reason) resp_headers = {} for header, value in resp.getheaders(): resp_headers[header.lower()] = value return resp_headers """ Request container delete directly from the container server. :param node: node dictionary from the ring :param part: partition the container is on :param account: account name :param container: container name :param conn_timeout: timeout in seconds for establishing the connection :param response_timeout: timeout in seconds for getting the response :returns: a dict containing the response's headers (all header names will be lowercase) """ resp_headers = {} for header, value in resp.getheaders(): resp_headers[header.lower()] = value return resp_headers def direct_post_container(node, part, account, container, headers, conn_timeout=5, response_timeout=15): """ Request container post directly from the container server. :param node: node dictionary from the ring :param part: partition the container is on :param account: account name :param container: container name :param conn_timeout: timeout in seconds for establishing the connection :param response_timeout: timeout in seconds for getting the response :param headers: headers to store as metadata :returns: a dict containing the response's headers (all header names will be lowercase) """ if headers is None: headers = {} path = '/%s/%s' % (account, container) with Timeout(conn_timeout): conn = http_connect(node['ip'], node['port'], node['device'], part, 'POST', path, headers=gen_headers(headers, True)) with Timeout(response_timeout): resp = conn.getresponse() resp.read() if not is_success(resp.status): raise ClientException( 'Container server %s:%s direct POST %s gave status %s' % (node['ip'], node['port'], repr('/%s/%s%s' % (node['device'], part, path)), resp.status), http_host=node['ip'], http_port=node['port'], http_device=node['device'], http_status=resp.status, http_reason=resp.reason) resp_headers = {} for header, value in resp.getheaders(): resp_headers[header.lower()] = value return resp_headers

commit_message:
Sendfile acceleration for GET requests

This is a bit of a hack that only works if you're using the eventlet's WSGI
server and nothing has changed too dramatically in various private interfaces
and non-standard APIs that it violates.

I still don't understand what we're doing about copyright notices.

Change-Id: Ic99d8c42037c9fe4af68e2dfeee6067e8aaac829

commit_message:
Base class for storage servers

DRY out storage server code a bit.  We opt *not* to have all the HTTP
methods in common use defined as "not implemented" since one does not
have to implement them.  We also ensure 100% coverage of the
common/test_server.py module using just common/test_server.py.

Change-Id: Idabe8e4c99415f0bedba93890300d5416626af3f

commit_message:
Tiny little last-minute changes

operations/backup -- made this a top-level head and fixed the
bullet lists

terminology:
amqp -- fixed bad reference list formatting
availability-zone -- fixed bad ref to host-aggregates
ceilometer -- fixed bad reference list formatting
ha -- show single-controller HA mode as available in 5.1
hadoop -- added link to Sahara article
host-aggregates -- fixed bad tag
sahara -- filled in description for sahara-plan and moved it

Change-Id: Ie1f8138ead170085f38b6730189ab393942674d7

Change-Id: I55419d910bfa7cd13f537d1c10e3e32db77bda1f

commit_message:
Return an error exit code if config is missing on start

Previously, we fixed a silent error in case pipeline was invalid in
the config. This is plugged elsewhere and is different: the Manager
class does not even attempt to load anything.

Note that this may be visible as a nonzero exit code from
"swift-init start all" and the like, if any server in the group
is missing. The command starts servers just like before, but
reports a status if anything was missing. This may trip shell
scripts that do set -e.

Change-Id: I55419d910bfa7cd13f537d1c10e3e32db77bda1f

commit_message:
Allow get_account and get_container to return an iterator

The full_listing option of get_account and get_container
builds and returns a list of accounts or containers that may
be really large.

To reduce memory consumption this patch adds the
full_listing_iter parameter that returns
an iterator instead of the a list of the full listing.
The caller will be able to consume it safely regarding
the memory usage.

This patch updates the full listing option of get_account
and get_container to use the iterators but keep the
compatibility by returning a list. This avoid
code duplication.

Change-Id: Ie4e394df2b323d8aa2665a9b13c49d4db9d1e0a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/45/74845/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ContainersIter(): def __init__(self, url, token, marker=None, limit=None, prefix=None, end_marker=None, http_conn=None): """ Iterator for listing containers for the account. :param url: storage URL :param token: auth token :param marker: marker query :param limit: limit query :param prefix: prefix query :param end_marker: end_marker query :param http_conn: HTTP connection object (If None, it will create the conn object) :returns: an Iterator over all the containers for the account :raises ClientException: HTTP GET request failed :raises StopIteration """ self.url = url self.token = token self.limit = min(limit, 10000) self.prefix = prefix self.next_marker = marker self.end_marker = end_marker self.http_conn = http_conn self.listing = None self.account_head = head_account(self.url, self.token, self.http_conn) def __iter__(self): return self def next(self): if self.listing: return self.listing.pop(0) else: self.listing = get_account(self.url, self.token, self.next_marker, self.limit, self.prefix, self.end_marker, self.http_conn)[1] if not self.listing: raise StopIteration else: self.next_marker = self.listing[-1]['name'] return self.listing.pop(0) class ObjectsIter(): def __init__(self, url, token, container, marker=None, limit=None, prefix=None, delimiter=None, path=None, end_marker=None, http_conn=None): """ Iterator for listing objects for the container. :param url: storage URL :param token: auth token :param container: container name to get a listing for :param marker: marker query :param limit: limit query :param prefix: prefix query :param delimiter: string to delimit the queries on :param end_marker: marker query :param path: path query (equivalent: "delimiter=/" and "prefix=path/") :param http_conn: HTTP connection object (If None, it will create the conn object) :returns: an Iterator over all the objects for the container :raises ClientException: HTTP GET request failed :raises StopIteration """ self.url = url self.token = token self.container = container self.limit = limit self.prefix = prefix self.delimiter = delimiter self.path = path self.next_marker = marker self.end_marker = end_marker self.http_conn = http_conn self.listing = None self.container_head = head_container(self.url, self.token, self.container, self.http_conn) def __iter__(self): return self def next(self): if self.listing: return self.listing.pop(0) else: self.listing = get_container(self.url, self.token, self.container, self.next_marker, self.limit, self.prefix, self.delimiter, self.end_marker, self.path, self.http_conn)[1] if not self.listing: raise StopIteration else: if not self.delimiter: self.next_marker = self.listing[-1]['name'] else: self.next_marker = \ self.listing[-1].get('name', self.listing[-1].get('subdir')) return self.listing.pop(0) end_marker=None, http_conn=None, full_listing=False, full_listing_iter=False): :param full_listing_iter: if True, return an iterator of the full listing, else returns a max of 10000 listings :returns: a tuple of (response headers, a list or iterator of containers) The response headers will be a dict and all header names will be lowercase. full_listing_iter: if True, return an iterator of the full listing, else returns a max of 10000 listings if full_listing_iter: o_iter = ObjectsIter(url, token, container, marker, limit, prefix, commit_message:
Bypass committing pending records from .pending file

In swift-{account, container}-info, get_info method call
commits all pending records found in .pending db file.
So this change will alllow user to bypass it with
new command line option.

Change-Id: Icfb412023ef2f3e58380146ad8a68f04457ebe0f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/51/85351/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parser.set_defaults(bypass_commits=False) parser.add_option( '-y', '--bypass-commits', action="store_true", dest="bypass_commits", help="Bypass committing records found in .pending files")

Zabbix documentation

planning/4450-monitoring -- main section for the monitoring tools.
Will eventurally introduce Ceilometer/MongoDB and Zabbix then source in
the individual files with details.

planning/monitoring/zabbix.rst -- information about planning for zabbix

Deleted operations/8550-zabbix -- how to use the dashboard and set templates

ref-arch/8100-zabbix.rst -- internals of Zabbix implementation

user-guide/config-environment/8000-zabbix-access.rst presents the
Settings page used to reset the Zabbix password.

terminology/z/zabbix -- terminology article

Note:  The screen where one assigns Zabbix to a role is in a different
commit so does not show in this commit at this time.

Change-Id: I6bac22838ccee596327508cb69df59b0aa49e7ee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/73/113773/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _zabbix-term: Zabbix ------ Zabbix is an open source cluster monitoring package. It is included as an Experimental package in Mirantis OpenStack 5.1; Fuel can install Zabbix in your OpenStack environment when the Experimental package is enabled. After deploying your environment with Zabbix enabled, you can access the dashboard using the link that is displayed on the Fuel dashboard. For Release 5.1, Zabbix can monitor the following: - Core OpenStack services: :ref:`nova-term`, :ref:`keystone-term`, :ref:`cinder-term`, :ref:`glance-term`, and :ref:`neutron-term`. - Core infrastructure components: :ref:`mysql-term`, :ref:`rabbitmq-term`, :ref:`haproxy-term`, memchached, and libvirtd. - Operating system statistics: Disk I/O, CPU load, free RAM, et cetera. For more information, see - :ref:`zabbix-plan` contains information about planning for Zabbix. - :ref:`zabbix-arch` describes how Zabbix is implemented in Mirantis OpenStack. - :ref:`assign-roles-ug` discusses the Fuel screen used to enable the Zabbix server. - :ref:`zabbix-ops` introduces the Zabbix dashboard. - `Zabbix documentation <https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/2.2/manual/concepts>`_.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/72/113972/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _ceilometer-mongodb-plan: Ceilometer and MongoDB ---------------------- Fuel can deploy :ref:`ceilometer-term`, the OpenStack Telemetry component. When enabled, Ceilometer collects and shares measurement data gathered from all OpenStack components. This data cam be used for monitoring and capacity planning purposes as well as for an alarming service. Ceilometer's REST API can also provide data to external monitoring software for a customer's billing system. Ceilometer can be configured to collect a large amount of metering data and thus perform a high volume of database writes. For example, with 100 resources and default configs Ceilometer collects around 16k samples per hour. Mirantis OpenStack 5.0 now defaults to installing MongoDB as the recommended back-end database for OpenStack Telemetry. The Fuel Master Node enables you to choose the installation of MongoDB as a role onto a node. This resolves the Ceilometer performance issues caused by the volume of concurrent read/write operations. commit_message:
Add support for OSprofiler

To be able to create profiling traces for Heat, the client should be
able to send special HTTP header that contains trace info.

Change-Id: I2ff833fac2dfe3bb0fcbd6a31c210db2935b72f1
Closes-bug: #1363782
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/18/118118/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heatclient.openstack.common import importutilsosprofiler_profiler = importutils.try_import("osprofiler.profiler") if osprofiler_profiler: parser.add_argument('--profile', metavar='HMAC_KEY', help='HMAC key to use for encrypting context ' 'data for performance profiling of operation. ' 'This key should be the value of HMAC key ' 'configured in osprofiler middleware in heat, ' 'it is specified in the paste configuration ' '(/etc/heat/api-paste.ini). ' 'Without the key, profiling will not be ' 'triggered even if osprofiler is enabled ' 'on server side.') profile = osprofiler_profiler and options.profile if profile: osprofiler_profiler.init(options.profile) if profile: trace_id = osprofiler_profiler.get().get_base_id() print("Trace ID: %s" % trace_id) print("To display trace use next command:\n" "osprofiler trace show --html %s " % trace_id)

commit_message:
glusterfs: edit config option specifying volume

glusterfs driver has an option to specify the GlusterFS volume to be
mounted on the Manila host. The GlusterFS volume to be mounted is
presently specified in a file, whose path is the config option
glusterfs_volumes_config. Instead have a string valued config option
in manila.conf that directly takes the same input.

Change-Id: I3f8734174db71ef232620c55d4ecdd2b5d0192ad
Closes-Bug: #1365941
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/83/119983/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CONF.set_default('glusterfs_target', '127.0.0.1:/testvol')

commit_message:
Fix error adding security groups to instances with nexus

Adding security group for running instance should not
invoke the nexus plugin. Current implementation does not
validate for the 'new_host_id' as assumes it as host migration
and fails.
Closes-Bug: #1365226

Change-Id: I9ab6b8438e6ee0698a8e2ae7ff7736f7c71b2370

subject: Verify requested size in volume.api create
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-18 00:26:08.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/test_volume.py', 'cinder/volume/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/6ac50f942f6a8f2c02524fcf50ad01ebafea7c64', 'message': "Verify requested size in volume.api create

Currently we're not checking that the input value requested
for size on volume create is valid, but taskflow portion of
the code expects it and as a result when it receives invalid
input we litter the logs with Trace messages.

This patch adds a check of the size requeste on create in the
volume.api code so we can return a proper exception to the caller
and minimizing how far down the path we need to go in order to fail.

Valid size argument requires input is an int and greater than zero.

Closes-Bug: 1370773

Change-Id: I41a7fce9a5be6e11140977853b14b68ea5c110d3
"}]
commit_message:
Verify requested size in volume.api create

Currently we're not checking that the input value requested
for size on volume create is valid, but taskflow portion of
the code expects it and as a result when it receives invalid
input we litter the logs with Trace messages.

This patch adds a check of the size requeste on create in the
volume.api code so we can return a proper exception to the caller
and minimizing how far down the path we need to go in order to fail.

Valid size argument requires input is an int and greater than zero.

Closes-Bug: 1370773

Change-Id: I41a7fce9a5be6e11140977853b14b68ea5c110d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/76/122276/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _size_is_valid(self, size): valid = True try: int(size) except ValueError: valid = False if size <= 0: valid = False return valid if not self._size_is_valid(size): msg = _('Invalid volume size provided for create request ' '(size argument must be an integer and greater ' 'than zero).') raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg) if volume_type and consistencygroup: "must be supported by this consistency group.")
deleted_lines: if consistencygroup: if not volume_type: msg = _("volume_type must be provided when creating " "a volume in a consistency group.") raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg) "must be supported by this consistency group).")

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-13 07:42:18.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/conf.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient/commit/16ac43a4049f5e03616403cca81ed68d59dbab54', 'message': "Stop using intersphinx

Remove intersphinx from the docs build as it triggers network calls that
occasionally fail, and we don't really use intersphinx (links other
sphinx documents out on the internet)

This also removes the requirement for internet access during docs build.

This can cause docs jobs to fail if the project errors out on

Change-Id: I71e941e2a639641a662a163c682eb86d51de42fb
Related-Bug: #1368910
"}]
commit_message:
Stop using intersphinx

Remove intersphinx from the docs build as it triggers network calls that
occasionally fail, and we don't really use intersphinx (links other
sphinx documents out on the internet)

This also removes the requirement for internet access during docs build.

This can cause docs jobs to fail if the project errors out on
warnings.

Change-Id: I71e941e2a639641a662a163c682eb86d51de42fb
Related-Bug: #1368910
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/10/121310/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: extensions = ['sphinx.ext.autodoc', 'oslosphinx']

commit_message:
Add stack-update argument for reset parameters

A new argument named clear-parameter for stack-update
will be supported by the heat engine to reset the value of the
parameter back to the default value. This argument can be
specified multiple times.

Partially-implements: blueprint troubleshooting-low-level-control
Partial-Bug: 1224828
Change-Id: Ib04dbc13978fdefd1bf3485f2654e139a3f1df8d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/65/109465/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @utils.arg('-c', '--clear-parameters', metavar='<KEY1;KEY2;...>', help='Remove the parameters from the set of parameters of current ' 'stack for the stack-update. The default value in the template ' 'will be used. This can be specified multiple times, or once with ' 'parameters separated by a semicolon.', action='append')@utils.arg('-c', '--clear-parameters', metavar='<KEY1;KEY2;...>', help='Remove the parameters from the set of parameters of current ' 'stack for the stack-update. The default value in the template ' 'will be used. This can be specified multiple times, or once with ' 'parameters separated by a semicolon.', action='append') if args.clear_parameters: fields['clear_parameters'] = \ utils.format_parameter_list(args.clear_parameters)

commit_message:
Add stack-update argument for patching parameters

A new argument named existing for stack-update will be
supported by the heat engine to use the parameters stored
in the Db.

Partially-implements: blueprint troubleshooting-low-level-control
Partial-Bug: 1224828
Change-Id: I30a2b223d7dd19a717ed989b419b1e6cb2ac143b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/05/109105/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @utils.arg('-x', '--existing-parameters', default=False, action="store_true", help='Re-use the set of parameters of the current stack. ' 'Parameters specified in --parameters will patch over the existing ' 'values in the current stack. Parameters omitted will keep ' 'the existing values.')@utils.arg('-x', '--existing-parameters', default=False, action="store_true", help='Re-use the set of parameters of the current stack. commit_message:
Handle federated tokens

Federated tokens don't include domains in the user object.
Keystoneclient should be able to estimate whether the token is a
federated one and, if so, don't expect user domain information.
In case of the federated token keystoneclient returns None in response
to user_domain_name and user_domain_id calls.

Co-Authored-By: Steve Martinelli <stevemar@ca.ibm.com>

Closes-Bug: #1346820
Change-Id: I3453275fa1b0a41b1c015b0c3a92895a77d69a41

commit_message:
Add a memory based shared cache

Simple dictionary based shared cache to speed up not just
a single set of nested wsdl/xsd(s) but also to share the
same cache, so when the same initial wsdl is loaded again
we still use the cached data from the previous wsdl load.
We essentially take the hit on the first wsdl load and
subsequent loads will be much faster. The cached items
expire in an hour to both clean up memory as well as
switch to newer wsdl/xsd(s) when the vCenter is upgraded
without needed a forced restart of nova compute process.

Change-Id: Ia2265f1f8ed5fe8b05770a5572f1516893b532a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.vmware refs/changes/97/116297/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class MemoryCache(suds.cache.ObjectCache): def __init__(self): self.cache = {} def get(self, id): return self.cache.get(id, None) def put(self, id, object): if (len(self.cache) > 32): self.cache = {} self.cache[id] = object _CACHE = MemoryCache() cache=_CACHE)

commit_message:
Add in atomic volume status updating

In order to be able to use the newly created state transitions
and validation functions, we need to create a backend db api
that allows us to *atomically* read, validate, then update the
status to the transitions desired end status.

This does use the with_lockmode() to do this, which it seems
like cinder is already using to do this in an atomic manner.

This will likely *not* work with current galera deployments.

Part of blueprint cinder-state-enforcer

Change-Id: I72b77461c27ac6c1d331563b74e23aa3e5054c2a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/99/110499/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @require_context def volume_transition_status(context, volume_id, new_status, validator_func=None): # NOTE(harlowja): we want this to occur in a single read/write transcation, # it needs to be verified if there is a better way to do this, either # than the slightly bad read, check, set (which suffers from the ABA # problem) or read consistency issues. session = get_session() with session.begin(): # NOTE(harlowja): if with_lockmode isn't supported, as in sqlite or # galera, then this has concurrency issues... ref = _volume_get_query(context, session=session, project_only=True).\ filter_by(id=volume_id).\ with_lockmode('update').\ first() if not ref: raise exception.VolumeNotFound(volume_id=volume_id) if validator_func is not None: validator_func(ref.status, new_status) ref.update({"status": new_status}) ref.save() return ref

commit_message:
Add a throttled scenario runner

Add a runner which can execute at a given rate for a given
number of scenario calls using a thread backed pool. This
allows for precise control over the rate at which scenarios
are ran.

Change-Id: I43bb60646df01713618dbf44915cbe550ed3d85a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/67/101067/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: THROTTLED = "throttled"

commit_message:
Removes unnecessary instructions in test_hypervapi

Lines have no actual effect on the tests. Removing them
will facilitate further unit tests.

Partial-Bug: #1220256

Change-Id: I805aba5e75f2640221b2dc0034950c0832841247

commit_message:
libvirt: Don't cache base image while migration

We should cache base image only if the disk file of instance is
not exists. while migration the disk is an whole one without
backing file even if it is qcow2 format, so nova needn't to
cache base image for instance, otherwise if the Glance image
is deleted, an ImageNotFound exception will be raised.
Here we also add target image exists checking after getting the
lock, otherwise we may get a broken image.

Closes-bug: #1298216
Closes-bug: #1298420
Change-Id: Ic10eb5f0027ff0647928dc04afaeb70c6593544b

commit_message:
Network: enable instance deletion when dhcp release fails

In the event that the 'dhcp_release' fails we should continue
with the deletion of the instance.

This will no longer the leave the instance in ERROR state.

Change-Id: Ie8259180a9df12865940907c728a8d9da3c9fda0
Closes-bug: #1289397

commit_message:
Support a common cache for metadata

Currently, the Nova metadata API stores its cache in memory, which
prevents it from being shared amongst multiple hypervisors and thus
reduces the hit rate. This blueprint proposes to optionally replace
the in-memory cache with dogpile.cache, allowing cache sharing between
hypervisors.

Change-Id: I7b2f6d3fd6408d0220439d8c74f5e1af22bb0583
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/46/121646/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== Support a common cache for metadata =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/common-nova-metadata-cache Currently, the Nova metadata API stores its cache in memory, which prevents it from being shared amongst multiple hypervisors and thus reduces the hit rate. This blueprint proposes to optionally replace the in-memory cache with dogpile.cache, allowing cache sharing between hypervisors. Problem description =================== Under heavy use, the Nova metadata API can be a significant performance bottleneck. This use pattern can be common with configuration management systems that draw their own metadata from Nova, for instance. In our experience, this bottleneck can be greatly improved by implementing a longer-lived, shared cache. I have already proposed a change, https://review.openstack.org/#/c/119421/, that will make the cache time configurable, but that is of limited benefit when the cache cannot be shared amongst multiple hypervisors. Proposed change =============== By using ``dogpile.cache`` to back the metadata cache, we can provide the option to share the cache between hypervisors by using memcached (for instance) and greatly increase the cache hit rate. The use of a common cache will be optional; the simple in-memory cache will still remain supported in order to keep simple deployments simple. Alternatives ------------ The only other way to increase cache hit rates is to increase the TTL of cache items, which we have already proposed. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- This actually makes it more difficult to launch a resource exhaustion attack, since the cache will no longer be stored in memory local to each hypervisor, but instead in a central system that can be protected (and set to expire the cache) independently. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ If the central caching feature is enabled, the operator can expect: * Memory usage on each individual hypervisor to decrease; * Cache hits on the metadata API (and thus performance thereof) to increase; * A new service (or, if using the same ``dogpile.cache`` backend as Keystone, an existing memcached service) that uses more memory. Other deployer impact --------------------- A new group, ``[metadata_cache]``, should be added to ``nova.conf``. It will contain the following options, all of which are exact analogs to the same options in the ``[cache]`` section of ``keystone.conf`` (see http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/configuration.html#caching-layer): * ``enabled`` * ``debug_cache_backend`` * ``backend`` * ``expiration_time`` * ``backend_argument`` The defaults will be:: enabled = yes debug_cache_backend = no backend = dogpile.cache.memory expiration_time = 15 backend_argument = This will mimic the current state of a completely in-memory cache. Developer impact ---------------- When writing unit tests that may use the metadata API, developers will need to select the memory cache backend. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: stpierre Work Items ---------- #. Write the caching layer module. This can be cribbed substantially from the existing Keystone key-value store, although it will be simpler in many ways because the data it will be storing is more predictable. #. Update the metadata request handler to use the new caching layer instead of the in-memory cache. Dependencies ============ None. ``dogpile.cache`` is already a global requirement. Testing ======= The change linked above already extends unit tests to actually test the metadata request handler, so they should be sufficient to test that portion of it. New tests will need to be added to test the caching layer, but since that's not exposed functionally no new tempest tests should be necessary. Documentation Impact ==================== The options listed above will need to be added to the documentation. Since the configuration is substantially similar to the Keystone caching layer, it is expected that much of the Keystone documentation can be borrowed whole cloth. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Fix concurrency issue with HeatStack.push

All changes to template made with call HeatStack.updateTemplate
while HeatStack.push is in progress will be lost after HeatStack.push
will be finished.

Co-Authored-By: Stan Lagun <slagun@mirantis.com>
Closes-bug: #1370503
Change-Id: Ia5c0457a2841bbcb30bc60f5ab99f7872a77b51e

commit_message:
javelin-resources: attach a volume to a server

In tempest/javelin2, we want to attach a volume to a server. For that we
need to bind the attachment in the resources.yaml.
Also, adding another volume to be sure we can create 2 volumes and
attach them to 2 differents instances.

Prereq for blueprint:javelin2
Change-Id: I71be5c0a2af69706f38f9f3a049d5591d838d8c0
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>

commit_message:
Allow users to clean up role assignments

This change allows users the ability to remove role assignments in the
event the user has been removed from the backend.

Closes-Bug: #1321378
Change-Id: I895e6e9718bc48344a53f192d5d56e6990da888e

added_lines: # FIXME(lbragstad): Move this test to tests/test_v3_assignment.py def test_delete_user_before_role_assignment_succeeds(self): """Call ``DELETE`` on the user before the role assignment.""" # Assign the user a role on the project collection_url = ( '/projects/%(project_id)s/users/%(user_id)s/roles' % { 'project_id': self.project_id, 'user_id': self.user_id}) member_url = ('%(collection_url)s/%(role_id)s' % { 'collection_url': collection_url, 'role_id': self.role_id}) self.put(member_url) # Delete the user self.delete('/users/%(user_id)s' % {'user_id': self.user['id']}) # Check if the user has the specified role on the project # FIXME(lbragstad): locally, this is raising a 401 Unauthorized self.head(member_url, expected_status=404) # Attempt revoking the role from the user self.delete(member_url, expected_status=404)

Add a run_tests.sh

An alternative to running tox, similar to other repos like glance and
nova.

added_lines: # Copyright 2010 United States Government as represented by the # Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. # All Rights Reserved. # # Copyright 2010 OpenStack Foundation # Copyright 2013 IBM Corp. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Installation script for glance_store's development virtualenv """ from __future__ import print_function import os import sys import install_venv_common as install_venv # noqa def print_help(): help = """ glance_store development environment setup is complete. glance_store development uses virtualenv to track and manage Python dependencies while in development and testing. To activate the glance_store virtualenv for the extent of your current shell session you can run: $ source .venv/bin/activate Or, if you prefer, you can run commands in the virtualenv on a case by case basis by running: $ tools/with_venv.sh <your command> Also, make test will automatically use the virtualenv. """ print(help) def main(argv): root = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__))) venv = os.path.join(root, '.venv') pip_requires = os.path.join(root, 'requirements.txt') test_requires = os.path.join(root, 'test-requirements.txt') py_version = "python%s.%s" % (sys.version_info[0], sys.version_info[1]) project = 'glance_store' install = install_venv.InstallVenv(root, venv, pip_requires, test_requires, py_version, project) options = install.parse_args(argv) install.check_python_version() install.check_dependencies() install.create_virtualenv(no_site_packages=options.no_site_packages) install.install_dependencies() install.run_command([os.path.join(venv, 'bin/python'), 'setup.py', 'develop']) print_help() if __name__ == '__main__': main(sys.argv)

commit_message:
Sync latest process and str utils from oslo

This backport the necessary changes to fix both issues:
* Make execute method clean password in exception
* Make sure mask_password works properly

Backport in oslo-incubator: 4cf1a2a158f7c3c21799bf2e6ba0e7b5fbc25d62

Closes-Bug: 1343604
Closes-Bug: 1345233
SecurityImpact

Change-Id: I3b49b1d667f6ade9ae3f6765d735440a3e838917

commit_message:
secgroup-create description is not optional

The description field to the Nova API for secgroup
create is not optional. This enforces the supplying
of the description field in novaclient as the Nova
call will fail if it is not supplied.

v3 version does not need to be updated as it was never
changed.

Change-Id: I6fc823990190b935a8e1214efc8c3ac3a0941abf
Closes-Bug: 1367121

commit_message:
Use VMware xsd and wsdl from oslo.vmware 0.5.0

The SPBM XSD and WSDL files are currently in the driver folder in
Cinder. The 0.5.0 release of oslo.vmware contains these files, so
Cinder can use them.

This patch is removing these files from Cinder and adds the
dependency to oslo.vmware.

Change-Id: I8250dd0adc28cc3859221be5d52bd46f2a88a677

subject: Update nova content for Juno
revisions:

I updated nova content in the installation guide for Juno
as follows:

1) Removed prompts specific to MySQL because most distributions
   will use MariaDB.
2) Explicitly created endpoint with 'regionOne' region to avoid
   inconsistent defaults.
3) Replaced 'auth_*' keys with 'identity_uri' key.
4) Moved glance configuration to [glance] section.
5) Recommended enabling verbose logging.
6) Added example command output and updated existing command
   output.

commit_message:
Update nova content for Juno

I updated nova content in the installation guide for Juno
as follows:

1) Removed prompts specific to MySQL because most distributions
   will use MariaDB.
2) Explicitly created endpoint with 'regionOne' region to avoid
   inconsistent defaults.
3) Replaced 'auth_*' keys with 'identity_uri' key.
4) Moved glance configuration to [glance] section.
5) Recommended enabling verbose logging.
6) Added example command output and updated existing command
   output.

Change-Id: Iad5c20e6562bcab83c6f0d5efccab566b3c18eae

commit_message:
Fix safe_encode func in strutils

Function 'safe_encode ' in 'strutils' module treats
'UTF-8' and 'utf-8' encodings as different.
But it should understand different aliases,
that have different text cases.

Change-Id: Ia080328a863318c852665f32d5fa1e5824f86d5d
Closes-Bug: #1342050

commit_message:
Add cpu_time in notification

This change adds a new polling task to retrieve the cpu_time of each
instances and stores thel in database.

And it will add this new information to the notification.

Partial implements usage-data-in-notification

Change-Id: I8e515c27e034156d9f263ef6660bd3047b0d5fe1

Fix autogenerate-config-docs link

Clicking the link to autogenerate-config-docs opens a blank page.
This patch fixes the link.

Change-Id: I60ca664de3f630058b8ce8e5a32340faf213d54b

commit_message:
Add explanation for installing Python development packages.

Installing software via pip requires the development files
as well. This update simply notes the package names per type
of package being used. Also added a note about extra packages
being possibly needed for building, such as with Tempest.

Partial-Bug: 1367526
Change-Id: I0430c08686012b31073ed98040b5e261a9205ca6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/91/120391/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Installing the clients entails compiling the actual source files and thus requires the related Python development package per your specific operating system and distribution. The package name for RPM-based distributions is <package>python-dev</package> and for DEB-based distributions it is <package>python-devel</package>.</para>

commit_message:
Create _member_ role instead of Member

Horizon moved to role _member_ in place of Member. With this change,
os-cloud-config creates _member_ instead of Member during Keystone
initialization.

Change-Id: Ia4d965335f900e03465f45c701f0bd5a3a4a0ea6

commit_message:
updated README.rst for API clients

Change-Id: Id26a4ca453cd3b6242c06ec3fce3e693325ea019
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-monascaclient refs/changes/30/121930/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: identify the monasca api endpoint. The user can obtain the token and endpoint using the keystone client api: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-keystoneclient/. The service catalog name for our API endpoint is "monasca". Start using the monascaclient API by constructing the monascaclient client.Client class. The Client class takes these parameters: api_version, endpoint, and token. The Client class is used to call all monasca-api resource commands (i.e. client.Client.metrics.create(fields)). Long running users of Client will recieve an indication that the keystone token has expired when they receive an HTTP response code of 401 Unathorized from the monasca-API. In this case it is up to the user to get a new token from keystone which can be passed into the client.Client.replace_token(token) method.

commit_message:
Added fuel-agent package

Thist package is supposed to be used for
image based provisioning.

Implements: blueprint image-based-provisioning
Change-Id: I29d0cd7bc850421fc57c84b02c59c8b2285f859d

commit_message:
Integration tests - Instances tests

    I added the _click_on_instances method to basepage, so that
    it can be used by go_to_instances_page method.

    I added the go_to_instances_page method to projectpage,
    so that it can be used for navigating to instances page.

    I added below methods for instances page:
    instancespage -
    create_instance method
    terminate_instance method
    associate_floatingip method
    disassociate_floating_ip method
    edit_instance method
    terminate_all_instances method
    soft_reboot_instance method
    hard_reboot_instance method
    rebuild_instance method

    I added the below methods for test_instances
    test_instances-
    test_create_instance method
    test_floating_ip_instance method
    test_soft_reboot_instance method
    test_hard_reboot_instance method
    test_rebuild_instance method
    test_terminate_all_instances method

    Co-Authored-By: Mohan Seri <mohan.seri@hp.com>
    Partially implements blueprint: launch-instance-selenium

Change-Id: I013e1b8442d7dedb864180ee940c64100b6886ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/26/122226/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import datetime from openstack_dashboard.test.integration_tests import helpers instances_availability_zone = 'nova' instances_flavor = 'm1.micro' instances_boot_source = 'Boot from image' instances_image_name = 'cirros-0.3.2-x86_64-uec (24.0 MB)' keypair_name = 'Keypair_' + str(datetime.datetime.now(). strftime("%Y%m%d%H%M%S")[2:]) instances_attributes = {'availability_zone': instances_availability_zone, 'flavor': instances_flavor, 'boot_source': instances_boot_source, 'image_name': instances_image_name, 'keypair': keypair_name } class TestInstances(helpers.TestCase): """This is a basic scenario to test: * login as a regular user * Perform Actions on Instances e.g.: Edit Instance, Pause Instance etc... """ def test_create_instance(self): """tests create instance: * Creates keypair * Creates and verifies Instance * Terminates and verifies Instance * Terminates keypair """ accesssecurity_page = self.home_pg.go_to_accesssecurity_page() keypair_page = accesssecurity_page.go_to_keypair_page() keypair_page.create_keypair(keypair_name) instances_page = self.home_pg.go_to_instances_page() self.Instance_check_locator = instances_page.create_instance( **instances_attributes) instance_status = instances_page.is_element_present( *self.Instance_check_locator) self.assertTrue(instance_status) self.Instance_check_locator = instances_page.terminate_instance() instance_status = instances_page.is_element_present( *self.Instance_check_locator) self.assertFalse(instance_status) accesssecurity_page = self.home_pg.go_to_accesssecurity_page() accesssecurity_page.go_to_keypair_page() keypair_page.delete_keypair(keypair_name) self.assertFalse(keypair_page.get_keypair_status(keypair_name)) def test_floating_ip_instance(self): """tests floating ip for instance: * Creates keypair * Creates and verifies Instance * Associate and Disassociate Floating IP and verifies * Terminates and verifies Instance * Terminate keypair """ accesssecurity_page = self.home_pg.go_to_accesssecurity_page() keypair_page = accesssecurity_page.go_to_keypair_page() keypair_page.create_keypair(keypair_name) instances_page = self.home_pg.go_to_instances_page() self.Instance_check_locator = instances_page.create_instance( **instances_attributes) instance_status = instances_page.is_element_present( *self.Instance_check_locator) self.assertTrue(instance_status) self.Instance_ip_locator = instances_page.associate_floatingip() instance_ip_status = instances_page.is_element_present( *self.Instance_ip_locator) self.assertTrue(instance_ip_status) self.instance_ip_locator = instances_page.disassociate_floating_ip() instance_ip_status = instances_page.is_element_present( *self.instance_ip_locator) self.assertFalse(instance_ip_status) self.Instance_check_locator = instances_page.terminate_instance() instance_status = instances_page.is_element_present( *self.Instance_check_locator) self.assertFalse(instance_status) accesssecurity_page = self.home_pg.go_to_accesssecurity_page() accesssecurity_page.go_to_keypair_page() keypair_page.delete_keypair(keypair_name) self.assertFalse(keypair_page.get_keypair_status(keypair_name)) def test_soft_reboot_instance(self): """tests soft reboot instance: * Creates keypair * Creates and verifies Instance * Soft Reboot Instance and verifies * Terminates and verifies Instance * Terminates keypair """ accesssecurity_page = self.home_pg.go_to_accesssecurity_page() keypair_page = accesssecurity_page.go_to_keypair_page() keypair_page.create_keypair(keypair_name) instances_page = self.home_pg.go_to_instances_page() self.Instance_check_locator = instances_page.create_instance( **instances_attributes) instance_status = instances_page.is_element_present( subject: Updating instance_uuid while booting multiple VMs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-01 14:10:26.000000000', 'files': ['nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ee7c48194254a8a7bbe4258a991ad2f9e09c094f', 'message': "Updating instance_uuid while booting multiple VMs

When multiple VMs are scheduled at a time (using --num-instances
parameter), request_spec['instance_properties']['uuid'] is always
set to the first VM's UUID. Thus, basing on this data may be
misleading. In this commit filter_properties are updated with the
valid instance_uuid so that filters and weighers are aware of what
instance is currently scheduled.

Closes-Bug: #1324030
Change-Id: I15db9e26de2331c063805bb22772b6b93fade00c
"}]
commit_message:
Updating instance_uuid while booting multiple VMs

When multiple VMs are scheduled at a time (using --num-instances
parameter), request_spec['instance_properties']['uuid'] is always
set to the first VM's UUID. Thus, basing on this data may be
misleading. In this commit filter_properties are updated with the
valid instance_uuid so that filters and weighers are aware of what
instance is currently scheduled.

Closes-Bug: #1324030
Change-Id: I15db9e26de2331c063805bb22772b6b93fade00c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/02/103902/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if instance_uuids: filter_properties['request_spec']['instance_properties']\ ['uuid'] = instance_uuids[num]

commit_message:
Improve list role assignments filters performance

When listing role assignments, we have the option
to filter them by actor, target and role. The
current implementation uses the standard
filtering the V3.wrap_collection. Given the large
number of individual assignments, this is pretty
inefficient.

This patch allows the controller to pass the
filters into the driver call, so the driver
filter the results itself and as result, then the
list size is kept a minimum.

Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Change-Id: I68a0c657725227fa5b7a14d0184d20e9b378c9a9
Closes-Bug: 1359231

inherited_to_projects=False) non_inherited_grant = {'user_id': self.user_two['id'], 'domain_id': domain['id'], 'role_id': self.role_admin['id']} inherited_grant = {'inherited_to_projects': 'projects', 'user_id': self.user_foo['id'], 'domain_id': domain['id'], 'role_id': self.role_member['id']} assignment_list = self.assignment_api.list_role_assignments( targets=[domain['id']]) self.assertEqual(2, len(assignment_list)) self.assertIn(non_inherited_grant, assignment_list) self.assertIn(inherited_grant, assignment_list) assignment_list = self.assignment_api.list_role_assignments( targets=[domain['id']], inherited_to_projects=True) self.assertEqual([inherited_grant], assignment_list) def test_list_role_assignments_combined_filters(self): # Create a new domain domain = {'id': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'name': uuid.uuid4().hex} self.assignment_api.create_domain(domain['id'], domain) # Create 'non-inherited' and 'inherited' roles non_inherited_role = {'id': 'non-inherited', 'name': uuid.uuid4().hex} self.assignment_api.create_role(non_inherited_role['id'], non_inherited_role) inherited_role = {'id': 'inherited', 'name': uuid.uuid4().hex} self.assignment_api.create_role(inherited_role['id'], inherited_role) # Create a new user in the new domain user = {'name': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'password': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'enabled': True, 'domain_id': domain['id']} user = self.identity_api.create_user(user) # Create a new group in the new domain group = {'name': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'domain_id': domain['id']} group = self.identity_api.create_group(group) # Create a new user in the new domain project = {'id': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'name': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'domain_id': domain['id']} self.assignment_api.create_project(project['id'], project) # Create assignments on project self.assignment_api.create_grant(user_id=user['id'], project_id=project['id'], role_id=non_inherited_role['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(group_id=group['id'], project_id=project['id'], role_id=non_inherited_role['id']) # Create non-inherited assignments on domain self.assignment_api.create_grant(user_id=user['id'], domain_id=domain['id'], role_id=non_inherited_role['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(group_id=group['id'], domain_id=domain['id'], role_id=non_inherited_role['id']) # Create inherited assignments on domain self.assignment_api.create_grant(user_id=user['id'], domain_id=domain['id'], role_id=inherited_role['id'], inherited_to_projects=True) self.assignment_api.create_grant(group_id=group['id'], domain_id=domain['id'], role_id=inherited_role['id'], inherited_to_projects=True) # Check role assignments for user on project assignment_list = self.assignment_api.list_role_assignments( actors=[user['id']], targets=[project['id']]) self.assertEqual([{'user_id': user['id'], 'project_id': project['id'], 'role_id': non_inherited_role['id']}], assignment_list) # Check role assignments for group on project assignment_list = self.assignment_api.list_role_assignments( actors=[group['id']], targets=[project['id']]) self.assertEqual([{'group_id': group['id'], 'project_id': project['id'], 'role_id': non_inherited_role['id']}], assignment_list) # Check role assignments for user on domain assignment_list = self.assignment_api.list_role_assignments( actors=[user['id']], targets=[domain['id']]) self.assertEqual(2, len(assignment_list)) self.assertIn({'user_id': user['id'], 'domain_id': domain['id'], 'role_id': non_inherited_role['id']}, assignment_list) self.assertIn({'inherited_to_projects': 'projects', 'user_id': user['id'], 'domain_id': domain['id'], 'role_id': inherited_role['id']}, assignment_list) # Check role assignments for group on domain assignment_list = self.assignment_api.list_role_assignments( actors=[group['id']], targets=[domain['id']]) self.assertEqual(2, len(assignment_list)) self.assertIn({'group_id': group['id'], 'domain_id': domain['id'], 'role_id': non_inherited_role['id']}, assignment_list) self.assertIn({'inherited_to_projects': 'projects', 'group_id': group['id'], 'domain_id': domain['id'], 'role_id': inherited_role['id']}, assignment_list)

commit_message:
Remove extra tenant_isolation parameter from config file

There was an "allow_tenant_isolation" option for compute and orchestration in
tempest/config.py.  There are no orchestration tests that use tenant_isolation,
removed.

Change-Id: Ifd98ec7df593387d63008ae9aa2bad1a8eb75c9f
Closes-Bug: #1340380

commit_message:
Volume types need to be specified when creating CG

When creating a consistency group, the scheduler will find a backend that
supports all input volume types. If volume types are not provided, the
default_volume_type in cinder.conf will be used, however, this could cause
inconsistent behavior in a user environment where the default_volume_type
is defined in some places but not in others. This fix removed the use of
default_volume_type for CG creation, added a check to verify that volume
types are provided when creating a CG.

When creating a volume and adding it to a CG, we need to make sure a
volume type is provided as well.

Change-Id: I078d4fdd8d92529e853be16272ad74d1e130f712
Closes-Bug: #1366371

deleted_lines: if volume_type and consistencygroup: "must be supported by this consistency group.")

commit_message:
Pass certificate, key and cacert to glanceclient

When glance is configured with ssl nova does not pass it's certificate,
key, or cacert.  Updated the code to pass the certificate, key, and cacert used in the
nova.conf file, if they are set.  Removed nested if statement.

Change-Id: I23fcd070994e435cb42aa09c824d13553503a7c5
Closes-Bug: #1279381

commit_message:
Getting rid of explicit 'start-task' property in workflow DSL

* Direct workflow handler now starts all the tasks with no inbound
  transitions so they can be more than one start tasks

commit_message:
BSN: Allow concurrent reads to consistency DB

Allow concurrent reads to the consistency DB since the
database lock the block was originally protecting against
is gone.

Closes-Bug: #1357102
Change-Id: I1618b4046e995c796757e723f99288e486683339

deleted_lines: from neutron.common import exceptionsclass MultipleReadForUpdateCalls(exceptions.NeutronException): message = _("Only one read_for_update call may be made at a time.") A wrapper object to keep track of the session and hold the SQL lock between the read and the update to prevent other servers from reading the hash during a transaction. if self.transaction: raise MultipleReadForUpdateCalls() self.transaction = self.session.begin(subtransactions=True)

commit_message:
Allow signalTransport option for sw deployments

Defaults to null (which in turn will cause heat to use its
default) but allows control over software deployment signalling,
in particular to use 'NO_SIGNAL' if required not to wait for success
or failure.

Change-Id: I7b8bb553724173261d9475e2d574fc0e413d2b3e

subject: Remove Contract on customUserData
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-09 16:57:14.000000000', 'files': ['meta/io.murano/Classes/resources/LinuxUDInstance.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/1c1144692ca89ed49a5df2cbac258fe4ed167d77', 'message': 'Remove Contract on customUserData

A common paradigm with userdata is to supply:
  userdata:
    str_replace:
      template: |
        <some script>
    params:
      param1: value1

With the contract on customUserData being a string, passing str_replace
as the argument results in coercion to a string, which makes it invalid.

Change-Id: I8bcf788522fc2428eaa3c8529ee11b5ed385099b
'}]
commit_message:
Remove Contract on customUserData

A common paradigm with userdata is to supply:
  userdata:
    str_replace:
      template: |
        <some script>
    params:
      param1: value1

With the contract on customUserData being a string, passing str_replace
as the argument results in coercion to a string, which makes it invalid.

Change-Id: I8bcf788522fc2428eaa3c8529ee11b5ed385099b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/52/120152/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Methods: initialize: Body: - $.customUserData: null Contract: $.notNull()
deleted_lines: Properties: customUserData: Contract: $.string() Usage: InOut Default: null Methods: Contract: $.string().notNull()

commit_message:
mkrepo.sh: make sure Packages files are properly sorted

Works around the base system installation failure (the error happens only
with Ubuntu 14.04). Note that the Packages files on Debian/Ubuntu mirrors
are sorted (alphabetically).

Change-Id: I20262e14b90010a67e7fc1d16843313481d0d6a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/35/120035/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sort_packages_file () { local pkg_file="$1" local pkg_file_gz="${pkg_file}.gz" local pkg_file_bz2="${pkg_file}.bz2" apt-sortpkgs "$pkg_file" > "${pkg_file}.new" || exit 1 if [ -e "$pkg_file_gz" ]; then gzip -c "${pkg_file}.new" > "$pkg_file_gz" fi if [ -e "$pkg_file_bz2" ]; then bzip2 -k "${pkg_file}.new" > "$pkg_file_bz2" fi mv "${pkg_file}.new" "${pkg_file}" } # Work around the base system installation failure. # XXX: someone should rewrite this script to use debmirror and reprepro for pkg_file in `find dists -type f -name Packages`; do sort_packages_file $pkg_file done

subject: Fix filter rule of hypervisor-servers search api
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-25 18:37:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6156c1676b730deaa8fba9dcec26b977515ec126', 'message': "Fix filter rule of hypervisor-servers search api

The response of the hypervisor-servers search api is contained
unintended servers.
The cause is the filter rule of sqlalchemy that is filtered by
the wildcard of hypervisor_hostname, as `%hostname%'.

This patch will enable to search servers by keyword without
wildcard of target hypervisor_hostname.
The api could also search by wildcard, if the keyword is contained it.

Change-Id: If71d1d5edc50d12a8cdf86de8365ce65be0d9be3
Closes-Bug: #1322921
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-05-26 16:15:05.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/integrated/v3/test_hypervisors.py', 'nova/tests/integrated/test_api_samples.py', 'nova/tests/db/test_db_api.py', 'nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/16bc39125a881fa597d73aa53470f850a2759e6f', 'message': 'Fix filter rule of hypervisor-servers search api

The response of hypervisor search APIs:
- /v2/{tenant_i}d/os-hypervisors/{hypervisor_hostname}/servers
- /v2/{tenant_i}d/os-hypervisors/{hypervisor_hostname}/search
- /v3/os-hypervisors/search?query={hypervisor_hostname}
are only support partial match search, not support exact match.
Therefore the result of `nova hypervisor-servers {hostname}`
can include untargeted hypervisor servers.

ex. There are 2 servers exist, test1 and test10. The command
result of `nova hypervisor-servers test1` includes both servers.

The cause is the filter rule of sqlalchemy that is filtered by
the wildcard of hypervisor_hostname, as `%hostname%`.

This patch will enable to search servers by not only partial search
but also exact match of the target hypervisor. The user may trigger
a partial search by including the % character, url-encoded, in the
API call, such as: "/v3/os-hypervisors/search?query=fake%25"

Change-Id: If71d1d5edc50d12a8cdf86de8365ce65be0d9be3
DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1322921
'}]
commit_message:
Fix filter rule of hypervisor-servers search api

The response of hypervisor search APIs:
- /v2/{tenant_i}d/os-hypervisors/{hypervisor_hostname}/servers
- /v2/{tenant_i}d/os-hypervisors/{hypervisor_hostname}/search
- /v3/os-hypervisors/search?query={hypervisor_hostname}
are only support partial match search, not support exact match.
Therefore the result of `nova hypervisor-servers {hostname}`
can include untargeted hypervisor servers.

ex. There are 2 servers exist, test1 and test10. The command
result of `nova hypervisor-servers test1` includes both servers.

The cause is the filter rule of sqlalchemy that is filtered by
the wildcard of hypervisor_hostname, as `%hostname%`.

This patch will enable to search servers by not only partial search
but also exact match of the target hypervisor. The user may trigger
a partial search by including the % character, url-encoded, in the
API call, such as: "/v3/os-hypervisors/search?query=fake%25"

Change-Id: If71d1d5edc50d12a8cdf86de8365ce65be0d9be3
DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1322921
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/78/95378/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: filter(field.like(hypervisor_match)).\

commit_message:
Align EC2 and metadata API with rest of nova in get_instance_az

The EC2 and metadata API had their own custom method to get an
instances AZ. This removes this and gets them to use the same paths
as the rest of nova.

Change-Id: I6ff80ce75214959bf7f2c02e6231c58b28600cf0
Closes-bug: #1314490

added_lines: #!/bin/bash # Until http://pad.lv/1101347 is fixed, we need this user to be able to # Log on to heat booted machines using the given SSH keypair set -uex # This is a specific workaround for Ubuntu 12.10 "quantal" distro=$(lsb_release -is || :) if [ "$distro" != "Ubuntu" ] ; then exit 0 fi codename=$(lsb_release -cs || :) if [ "$codename" != "quantal" ] ; then exit 0 fi # Setup ec2-user as expected by HEAT if ! getent passwd ec2-user ; then useradd -m -G admin ec2-user -s /bin/bash fi if ! [ -e /etc/sudoers.d/ec2-user ] ; then echo "ec2-user ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD:ALL" > /etc/sudoers.d/ec2-user chmod 0440 /etc/sudoers.d/ec2-user visudo -c fi # We must pin to this fixed cloud-init from the demo ppa to ensure keys # are installed. This can be removed if http://pad.lv/1100920 is ever # fixed in the distro add-apt-repository -y ppa:tripleo/demo apt-get update cat > /etc/apt/preferences.d/cloud-init-from-ppa <<EOF Package: cloud-init Pin: release o=LP-PPA-tripleo-demo Pin-Priority: 900 EOF # Should pull from demo PPA if cloud-init exists there. # Since this is Ubuntu only, the --force-yes is OK install-packages --force-yes cloud-init

commit_message:
Make sure the name in setup.cfg is murano-agent not muranoagent

This also reverts the following oslo-incubator commit
https://github.com/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/f6a1848688483c34be2fb5ba2544f80bc659a26c

Change-Id: I467699eb70c5332d097b072e6696cb21f6c6de63
Closes-bug: #1367543

Fixing workflow handlers to return all possible commands

added_lines: def _find_next_commands(self, task_db): """Finds commands that should run after completing given task. commands = [] commands = self._get_next_commands(on_error, ctx) commands = self._get_next_commands(on_success, ctx) commands += self._get_next_commands(on_complete, ctx) LOG.debug("Found commands: %s" % commands) return commands def _get_next_commands(self, cmd_conditions, ctx): commands = [] for t_name, condition in cmd_conditions.iteritems(): if not condition or expr.evaluate(condition, ctx): commands.append(self.build_command(t_name)) return commands def build_command(self, cmd_name): cmd = commands.get_reserved_command(cmd_name) return cmd or commands.RunTask(self.wf_spec.get_tasks()[cmd_name])
deleted_lines: def _find_next_tasks(self, task_db): """Finds tasks that should run after completing given task. task_specs = [] task_specs = self._get_tasks_to_schedule(on_error, ctx) task_specs = self._get_tasks_to_schedule(on_success, ctx) task_specs += self._get_tasks_to_schedule(on_complete, ctx) LOG.debug("Found tasks: %s" % task_specs) return task_specs def _get_tasks_to_schedule(self, task_conditions, ctx): task_specs = [] for t_name, condition in task_conditions.iteritems(): if not condition or expr.evaluate(condition, ctx): task_specs.append(self.wf_spec.get_tasks()[t_name]) return task_specs

commit_message:
Refactoring engine using abstraction of command

* Refactored engine completely
* Rearranged utility classes to remove circular dependencies
* Fixed policies
* Fixed workflow handlers to generate commands
* Fixed all unit tests
* Other minor changes

Change-Id: Ie0c4d8222ff701e50876a8fe4660e297fc4bc4af

added_lines: @staticmethod def _process_commands(self, commands, exec_db, wf_handler): for cmd in commands: cmd.run(exec_db, wf_handler) def run_task(self, task_id): # TODO(rakhmerov): It's not valid anymore.
deleted_lines: from mistral import exceptions as exc def _process_task_specs(self, task_specs, exec_db, wf_handler): LOG.debug('Processing workflow tasks: %s' % task_specs) # DB tasks & Data Flow properties db_tasks = self._prepare_db_tasks(task_specs, exec_db, wf_handler) # Running actions/workflows. self._run_tasks(db_tasks, task_specs) def _prepare_db_tasks(self, task_specs, exec_db, wf_handler): wf_spec = spec_parser.get_workflow_spec(exec_db.wf_spec) new_db_tasks = self._create_db_tasks(exec_db, task_specs) # Evaluate Data Flow properties ('parameters', 'in_context'). for t_db in new_db_tasks: task_spec = wf_spec.get_tasks()[t_db.name] data_flow.prepare_db_task( t_db, task_spec, wf_handler.get_upstream_tasks(task_spec), exec_db ) return new_db_tasks def _create_db_tasks(exec_db, task_specs): new_db_tasks = [] for task_spec in task_specs: t = db_api.create_task({ 'execution_id': exec_db.id, 'name': task_spec.get_name(), 'state': states.RUNNING, 'spec': task_spec.to_dict(), 'parameters': None, 'in_context': None, 'output': None, 'runtime_context': None }) new_db_tasks.append(t) return new_db_tasks @staticmethod def _before_task_start(task_db, task_spec): for p in policies.build_policies(task_spec.get_policies()): p.before_task_start(task_db, task_spec) @staticmethod def _run_tasks(self, db_tasks, task_specs): for t_db, t_spec in zip(db_tasks, task_specs): self._before_task_start(t_db, t_spec) # Policies could possibly change task state. if t_db.state == states.RUNNING: self._run_task(t_db, t_spec) def _run_task(self, t_db, t_spec): if t_spec.get_action_name(): self._run_action(t_db, t_spec) elif t_spec.get_workflow_name(): self._run_workflow(t_db, t_spec) def run_task(self, task_id): @staticmethod def _resolve_action(wf_name, wf_spec_name, action_spec_name): action_db = None if wf_name != wf_spec_name: # If workflow belongs to a workbook then check # action within the same workbook (to be able to # use short names within workbooks). # If it doesn't exist then use a name from spec # to find an action in DB. wb_name = wf_name.rstrip(wf_spec_name)[:-1] action_full_name = "%s.%s" % (wb_name, action_spec_name) action_db = db_api.load_action(action_full_name) if not action_db: action_db = db_api.load_action(action_spec_name) if not action_db: raise exc.InvalidActionException( "Failed to find action [action_name=%s]" % action_spec_name ) return action_db def _run_action(self, task_db, task_spec): exec_db = task_db.execution wf_spec = spec_parser.get_workflow_spec(exec_db.wf_spec) action_spec_name = task_spec.get_action_name() action_db = self._resolve_action( exec_db.wf_name, wf_spec.get_name(), action_spec_name ) action_params = task_db.parameters or {} if action_db.spec: # Ad-hoc action. action_spec = spec_parser.get_action_spec(action_db.spec) base_name = action_spec.get_base() action_db = self._resolve_action( exec_db.wf_name, wf_spec.get_name(), base_name ) base_params = action_spec.get_base_parameters() if base_params: action_params = expr.evaluate_recursively( base_params, action_params ) else: action_params = {} self._executor_client.run_action( task_db.id, action_db.action_class, action_db.attributes or {}, action_params ) @staticmethod def _resolve_workflow(parent_wf_name, parent_wf_spec_name, wf_spec_name): wf_db = None if parent_wf_name != parent_wf_spec_name: # If parent workflow belongs to a workbook then # check child workflow within the same workbook # (to be able to use short names within workbooks). # If it doesn't exist then use a name from spec # to find a workflow in DB. wb_name = parent_wf_name.rstrip(parent_wf_spec_name)[:-1] wf_full_name = "%s.%s" % (wb_name, wf_spec_name) wf_db = db_api.load_workflow(wf_full_name) if not wf_db: wf_db = db_api.load_workflow(wf_spec_name) if not wf_db: raise exc.WorkflowException( "Failed to find workflow [name=%s]" % wf_spec_name ) return wf_db def _run_workflow(self, task_db, task_spec): parent_exec_db = task_db.execution parent_wf_spec = spec_parser.get_workflow_spec(parent_exec_db.wf_spec) wf_spec_name = task_spec.get_workflow_name() wf_db = self._resolve_workflow( parent_exec_db.wf_name, parent_wf_spec.get_name(), wf_spec_name ) wf_spec = spec_parser.get_workflow_spec(wf_db.spec) wf_input = task_db.parameters start_params = {'parent_task_id': task_db.id} for k, v in wf_input.items(): if k not in wf_spec.get_parameters(): start_params[k] = v del wf_input[k] self._engine_client.start_workflow( wf_db.name, wf_input, **start_params )

commit_message:
Add a doc note about the vendor_passthru endpoint

Add a doc note about the vendor_passthru endpoints to
doc/source/dev/drivers.rst, and update the list of short links on that
page.

Change-Id: Ib6cc9d507dc5907e5c38d107cfea48c987793787
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/78/121678/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ../api/ironic.drivers.agent ../api/ironic.drivers.drac ../api/ironic.drivers.ilo Vendor Passthru --------------- Drivers may implement a "vendor passthrough" API, which becomes accessible via POST to the /v1/{NODE}/vendor_passthru/method={METHOD} endpoint. Beyond basic checking, Ironic does not introspect the message body and simply passes it to the Node's driver. It should be noted that this API end point is synchronous and blocking, and therefor serialized. An API call will return when the Node's driver has finished processing the request; during that time, other calls to this endpoint for this node will return a 409 CONFLICT error.

commit_message:
On lock removal validate that they key was actually deleted

Instead of assuming the lock was released (when it might have
not been) be more reliable and return whether it really was
or was not by validating the reply.

Change-Id: I70b2e1946d5101c7fbbf4ed9f15007bb98e92581

commit_message:
Fix for missing notification in Sahara OSTF tests

Platform test for Sahara can fail if default security group has no "TCP"
rules. In accordance with that the check for "TCP" rules was added
to reduce the number of such failures.

Closes-Bug: #1342639

Change-Id: I083eaac15748422c4b2713ab3a42064d68c12c4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-ostf refs/changes/83/117483/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not self.get_tcp_rules_for_default_security_group(): LOG.debug('There are no "TCP" rules for the default security ' 'group. At a minimum rule for port 22 (SSH) must be ' 'added to the security group.') self.skipTest('There are no "TCP" rules for the default security ' 'group. Please, refer to the Mirantis OpenStack ' 'documentation to know which "TCP" rules should be ' 'added to the security group ' '(http://docs.mirantis.com/openstack/fuel/fuel-5.0/' 'user-guide.html#platform-tests-description).')

commit_message:
Add required statement for multipath and E-Series

This adds a blurb to denote that multipath is a required setting for
operating the Cinder E-Series and EF-Series driver, along with the
appropriate configuration options for cinder.conf and nova.conf.

Change-Id: I658c9d73873677cdb069d736f8881cb81597025f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/29/122129/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>The use of multipath and DM-MP are required when using the OpenStack Block Storage driver for E-Series. In order for OpenStack Block Storage and OpenStack Compute to take advantage of multiple paths, the following configuration options must be correctly configured:</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>The <option>use_multipath_for_xfer</option> should be set to <literal>True</literal> in <filename>cinder.conf</filename> within the driver stanza.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>The <option>iscsi_use_multipath</option> should be set to <literal>True</literal> in <filename>nova.conf</filename> within the <literal>[libvirt]</literal> stanza.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist>netapp_storage_pools = <replaceable>pool1,pool2</replaceable> use_multipath_for_image_xfer = True</programlisting>

Related-Bug: #1361629

commit_message:
Fix VM load release in Heat autoscaling tests

Make load release command more targeted in killing a CPU loading process
by getting its actual PID.

The exact implementation in two ssh commands is due to pecularities of
bash in Fedora 17 used as image for VMs in autoscaling test.

Change-Id: I9e0b67bffa7a944241f1e15ed92e29b0b6e040dd
Related-Bug: #1361629
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-ostf refs/changes/31/121631/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pid = self._run_ssh_cmd(connection_string + " ps -ef | grep \"cat /dev/urandom\" " "| grep -v grep | awk '{print $2}'")[0] return self._run_ssh_cmd(connection_string + " kill -9 %s" % pid.strip())[0]

This patch set add unit tests for "ironic port-test" command.
